name: fachan

attributes.attribute: haunted the wilder districts of Scotland
held a flail covered with iron apples
hopping about on its single leg
cast curses by standing on one leg with an arm in the air
related to the posture of standing on one leg with an arm in the air

entities.type: cast curses by standing on one leg with an arm in the air
related to the posture of standing on one leg with an arm in the air

sources: Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: Folklore in Scotland has it that there was a one-legged, one-eyed monster popularly known as the fachan (athach). This creature was found in the more remote regions of Scotland, terrorizing people who wandered in its habitat. The fachan had one arm growing right from its chest, which it used to hold a flail covered in iron apples. While hopping about on its solitary leg, the fachan would use the flail to attack anyone who passed by. The fachan had two forms- the Athach and the dìreach. The dìreach haunted the desolate Glen Eitive. People believe that the stories surrounding the fachan may have been born out of a fear of a Druid casting spells by standing on one leg with an arm raised, as seen in Glám Dícenn.
